reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s opening move: using evolution/engineering/sailing analogies to argue that “narrow target” does not imply near-zero expected value because agents/processes can hone in on the target. That is part of the framing and does some argumentative work, but the essay’s main conclusions rely more on detailed later discussion (convergence, motivation, trade, threats, blockers), so centrality is moderate-low. The objection has some force: evolution and design have comparatively clear feedback/selection signals, whereas “the good” is contested and may not supply an analogous optimization gradient, so the analogies don’t by themselves justify optimism. However, the essay itself later emphasizes exactly these complications (disputed good, lack of WAM-convergence, etc.), so the critique only partially weakens the overall position rather than refuting it. The critique is largely correct and clearly stated, with no fluff and focused on a single issue, though it overstates a bit by implying the essay “never shows” relevant structure when later sections do address the disanalogy.
title: Disputed values lack the clear feedback loops present in the paper's analogies
